bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Frederick F. Russell, September 13, 1923

div1.p: Hanson states that he does not think there is yellow fever in Bucaramanga and that the purported cases, which he describes, are not yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Frederick F. Russell, September 13, 1923
div1.opener:
Carter
Bucaramanga, September 13, 1923
Dr. F.F. Russell, General Director,
The International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York City.
My dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter
of August 6th, with reference to the report of yellow fever near
Lake Maracaibo in 1921, with copies of letters regarding the same.
We will undoubtedly get further information on this when we go to
Cucuta, which we expect to do by way of Maracaibo.

I expect Dr. Roberto Serpa to go to Cucuta next week, I
had planned for him to leave this week, but have been unable to
get the necessary arrangements made, on account of spending a
great deal of time in the investigation of the sick of this place.

In so far as the sick of this place are concerned, none
of those seen by me since my arrival have had symptoms which would
allow a diagnosis of yellow fever. If this is yellow fever it is an
entirely different different type of yellow fever from that which
we had on the Pacific coast of Peru. What I think has happened is
that, the epidemic here is over for the following reasons:

According
to the information available here the epidemic of Bucaramanga be-
gan sometime last year, some say in September, others say later, but
by general consent it appears to have been before last December.
Accepting such an assertion as true, and knowing that no work
was done against the breeding of the Stegomyia, it is quite rea-
sonable to conclude that the force of the epidemic had practically
spent itself before the arrival of the Commission of Investigation,
and the few typical cases seen by them were among the last to pre-
sent themselves.

As I stated in a previous communication, the cases which I
have seen, have not had black vomit, very few have had any noticable
nausea, none have had the congestive gingivitis, nor any spontaneous
bleeding from the gums, none have had nosebleed, none have had the
congestion in the conjunctiva nor a subsequent yellow discolora-
tion, none have had a typical albuminuria, and in fact in only one
instance was there a marked amount of albumen, and that paitent
was in a washerwoman who was found at her work on the second day
after this observation was made. None have been found with a brady-
cardia in convalescence nor has the typical prostrated condition
been seen. The priest of whom I spoke in a former letter I am

September 13, 1923.
considering as a doubtful or possible case in as much as I did
not see him until the 11th day, I do not feel that I am in a
position to say one way or the other.

The waiter at the Hotel Contenintal, who was taken sick
last Friday evening, and was diagnosed as yellow fever by Dr.
McCormick, did not have albuminuria, nor bleeding gums not with-
standing the fact that he has considerable pyorrhea, he did not
have the congestion of the eyes nor a subsequent interic dis-
coloration, nor the prostration characteristic of yellow fever.
In examining the blood Dr. McCormick found the organism which he
has reported in these cases which have presented themselves here
lately. I also took bilod smears as I thought from the initial
symptoms that it might be a case of malaria, but on examination
I found the spirochaete of relapsing fever, on two successive da
days. He ran a fever for a little over four days, yesterday and
today he has been up and waiting on the table, and does not show
any of the characteristic prostration following yellow fever. We
are looking for the relapse to occur next week when we will take
more blood smears and also administer someneacsalvarsan. I be-
lieve that many of the recent febrile cases here are cases of
relapsing fever, as we have received such histories in several
and have obtained the spirochaete in three. This spirochaete is
an entirely different organism from the one which McCormick is
reporting. Dr. Serpa who has seen most of the recent fever cases
with me states that they are different from those seen here in
the earlier part of the epidemic.

At this very moment Dr. McCormick has just called here at
the office to advise me that a child which was reported this mor-
ning but which I could not see on account of wanting to get my
mail ready, as we have outgoing mail tomorrow, but which I asked
Dr. Serpa to see, has the organisms of relapsing fever, but she also
has this other organism which McCormick is finding. Dr. Serpa's
opinion was that it was not a case of yellow fever. I have blood
smears from this case which I will stain and examine tomorrow.

The curious thing about this organism of McCormicks is
that it is not seen in very large numbers immediately upon taking
the blood smear. The technique is the following:

A drop of blood is
taken either by the ordinary lancet, or a few drops are drawn
from the vein, this is mixed with a solution of sodium citrate in
normal saline, and as far as I have been able to note the propor-
tions of blood and the saline-citrate mixture is about 1 to 2 or
varying between that on up to about 1 to 4 dilution. A slide is
cleaned cleaned free from grease, coverslip cleaned and then placed
on the slide in such a manner that one edge of the coverslip just
coincides with the edge of the slide, the two sides of the cover
slip which are perpendicular to the edge of the slides are sealed
with parrafine wax, leaving the the other two edges (oppo-
site one another) free so as to form a sort of broad flat capill-
ary space, but very thin. The edge of the slide and slip is then
touched to a large drop of the blood-citrate mixture, and a very
fine film of the mixture is obtained. The remaining two edges of
Dr. F.F. Russell
3
September 13, 1923
of the coverslip are sealed in the same way, and the preparation
is then examined under the Special high dry of the Zeiss Micro-
scope, with the high oculars, using the dark field.

When these preparations are first seen under the scope,
or rather when first prepared there often is very little to be
seen, after about 15 to 20 minuits a filamentous “spirochaetoid”(?)
organism is seen, which has an appearance as is proceeding from
the redblood corpuscle. As time advances these increase. Some
are found free in the plasma of the preparation, usually rather
small, about four to seven micra in length. I have not been able
to satisfy myself that this “organisms” has a true motility, it
appears to me to be a Brownonian motion. A curious thing is that
he finds these “spirochaetes” in all the cases which he examines,
whether early in the disease or as late as the 24th day (ywenty-
fourth day). He states that they are also found in the guinae
pigs here.

Last night he called me to see a new feature of this thing,
stating that he had found a way of fragmenting the redblood
cells and in such fields he had very large numbers of these
long thin filiform structures, which in the portion next to the
red cells, the portion which appeared to be attached, was rather
straight in appearance for a distance of about 8 to 12 micra,
and then beyond that they appeared twisted, or coiled like a
closely coiled spring, and others seemed as if doubed back on
on themselves in the distal portions. The movement was of a
wavy nature, with a tendency to coiling and unceiling. It is
very difficult to give you anything like a clear word picture
of this phenomenon, and what significance it has I do not pre-
sume to say. A great deal of publicity has been given to the
thing here. They at first seemed to have the impression that
it was the organism of Noguchi, and were inclined to accept
this finding as diagnostic. This I think I have succeeded in
dispelling. Since I gave McCormick two of Noguchi's pamphlets
to read, he is satisfied that he is not dealing with the Lepto-
spira icteroides. The impression now is that they have something
entirely new, and the author of the phenomenon insists that it
(the disease) is the same as that which the Commission saw
when here.

Some of the men want the Board to send an expert
bacteriologist to investigate the discovery, and have asked me
to take the matter up with you. Were it not so difficult
get her with the necessary apparatus it might be worth while you
to send some one, as there is a world of materials here of
study, it may be advantageous to clear this thing up as there
is some tendency to question whether or not there was yellow
fever, in as much as this thing is claimed to occur among the
present febrile cases.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully yours, I am inclosing some extra copies of this letter as Drs. Noguchi,
White and Carter may be interested.
H.H.
